Regarding Touch Bar, I’m one of those that haven’t used it much to be fair, although when I look at my laptop and see it, I really appreciate it. Right now, at least for me it’s more cool than useful. But I’ve always expected the Touch Bar to take the whole keyboard region… Think about it, there wouldn’t be the need to manufacture MacBooks with specific keyboard layouts, depending on region. The keyboard could adapt way better to the use case if it’s dynamic. As for physical feedback on the keyboard I find myself not needing it as much — we should all be used to type directly on our smartphones’ screens by now, and you get the visual feedback directly on the UI… so I’m not sure if this would be the type of situation of taking 1 step back to take 2 in front in the future, but I feel that taking out the Touch Bar is definitely a step back.

Any consideration going forward must include support for Thunderbolt 4 / USB4 as that is the new emerging standard. To do otherwise is going backwards.

I had the Mac Mini M1 on order but then decided to cancel it. Why? First, I normally avoid 1st Gen any thing. Better to wait for 2nd gen or beyond. Secondly, there already exists in the Mac Mini parts list a silicon board with 10Gbe support and yet, Apple does not make it available as an option. They had it before in the Mac Mini, why not now? Marketing strategy, not lack of technical ability. Also, they had 4 thunderbolt ports previously now only 2?! Apple will use these upgrades to convince the consumer to outlay more money for another round of upgrading equipment. Why give it to the consumer all at once when they can 'piece meal' the technology for more profits down the road. Of course, this is personal speculation, but I believe I am pretty much on target in my analysis and assessment. The new Intel Phantom Canyon NUC has thunderbolt 4 ports, so there is no reason Apple, of all companies, can not do it. The end of touch bar! Thank the lord! Who needed this gimmicky sh*t, all it did was make a MBP even more expensive - as if 400$ for a ram upgrade weren't enough. Next step should be to stop maximizing profits with cheap tricks such as glueing the components to the chassis, or worse, soldering them on. While I was hoping in the past that the bright future would mean modular notebooks with upgradeable graphics cards - the exact opposite happened: N.O.T.H.I.N.G is upgradeable any more. Thanks for nothing, Apple. Yes, I am in the apple universe, writing this from a MacBook pro - but there's a reason that this said MBP is a Late 2013 STILL. In 2021. What has happened since this version (still the best one ever made in my opinion)? Keyboards not working, thermal throttling, NO components upgradeable any more (mine could still upgrade the SSD at least), crazy price upgrades etc. The M1 16" will be the first one that seems worth an upgrade - and dumping the worthless touchbar is a good start. Increased battery life is awesome, too. But the components will probably still be soldered on. And everybody seems to be ok with it. Why?

Can we just take a moment to appreciate how dumb and stubborn Apple is to constantly give us things and/or take them away because "they know better" only to have to walk it back years later. I bought my current 2017 MacBook Pro to replace my old one without a lot of research and was absolutely dumbfounded when there were no ports to be found on the stupid thing and the only 2 ports there are are one the same side and so close to each other that it can be really tricky to plug 2 things in at once!! If they had at least put one on each side it a) wouldn't matter how big the item is and b) would at least allow you to plug the power cord in from either side which would be really convenient for those times when the cord barely reaches. Then the keyboard fiasco where they "improved" a perfectly functional and non-problematic keyboard design that nobody complained about to one that not only feels terrible but is absolutely plagued by problems to the point that they got sued and have had to replace tens of thousands of them for free well after the warranty period and sometimes even multiple times for the same laptop. It's one thing to try something new and not have it succeed but Apple is so damn stubborn that they refuse to listen to their customers and keep shoving the same garbage down their customers' throats. I'm not saying that their products in general are garbage, for the most part they're great but they always have to do a few stupid things in some pompous attempt to push the envelope instead of listening to the requests, recommendations, and complaints of their customers.

I love my touch bar! I’ve had it since it’s release on my 13” MBP.
I am a student and it’s super efficient when I’m word processing to change things like font color or predictive typing, especially when typing in foreign languages that I’m studying! I also love the Apple Pay 💰 animation and the video controls like; Pause, Picture in Picture, 15 seconds back/ forward.
I love being able to hold down the Siri icon while speaking instead of having to use a two finger keyboard short cut or having to drag my cursor over to the GUI Siri on a 13” screen.
Using the calculator app with the touch bar also is super nice! Again no need to “shift & =” for addition or dragging my cursor to the addition +.
Here’s another one, notifications/ alerts I can just tap my Touch Bar and done ✅. Again I don’t have to drag my cursor to confirm that I want to put my computer to sleep!
Repetitive tasks like in the mail app for example I can just;
click email 📧, Touch Bar “delete”
click email 📧, Touch Bar “spam folder” and no need to drag cursor all the way to the top of the screen!
Conclusion,
As a student and media enthusiast I absolutely love my Touch Bar. It helps me with my productivity and the colorful animations make my computer feel alive and aware of my input needs. Touch Bar also allows me to not need to remember all these keyboard shortcuts!

On the Touch Bar. I use it all the time. I think it's fantastic for quick changing of brightness and volumes. Much quicker than a button, as it used to be (Or still is on non-touchbar models). I find the quick swiping to get where I want it to be feels excellent, and allows me to make micro adjustments that take no time at all. 
I also use it for quick shortcuts (such a locking the MacBook), which is fine, but a dedicated button or shortcut for that would work better.
I'd be sad for it to go, but if they wanted to keep it, they really need to think of better implementations and ways it improves workflows. It is, as a product, fine. But that's all.

I think at this point I would actually hate to loose the Touch Bar. Honestly, I never ever used the function keys anyway. The Touch Bar actually does something. Now, I can scrub audio and videos... including Instagram videos I don't want to be forced to sit through on my phone. There are a few functions in Illustrator or Sketch or Keynote that are faster on the Touch Bar. But, without the Touch Bar, those functions would have to be menu clicks — far worse. I’m by no means a massive fan of the OLED Touch Bar on the newer MacBook Pro’s but I really am gonna miss it. I’m picking up the M1 Pro later this week (probably the last ever model to ship with it) so now I’ll still be able to use it for another 6-7 years, but I loved how it changed contexts based on what program I was in. The photo app really took advantage of its ability to scroll through pictures horizontally with shortcut editing tools when you opened one, and I loved the scrubbing feature in Final Cut. Even just typing and having spelling corrections and emojis constantly pop up above my keyboard, yet beneath my screen became a really pleasant convenience that lent itself well to my workflow. I’m bummed it was never really improved or evolved on subsequent Macs.

Why haven't I heard anyone talk about the 2 USB-C/Lightining 4 limitation and the Wi-Fi chip being degraded? All Intel Macs had 3 Spatial Streams; now, they only have 2. That's a big hit on speeds. For example, a device with 3 spatial streams or MIMO connected to a 40 MHz channel would get 860Mbps bandwidth, while a 2 spatial stream device only gets 574Mbps, big difference!

Back to the USB-C, All the M1 Macs dropped only have 2 ports. Mini, Pro, and Air all only support 2. Is that changing?

You mean mini led?

I love my touchbar. With BetterTouchTool and Keyboard Meastro it is a great way to use macro's, switch programs and use less of my mouse. Yes, you can set macro's to keys (and believe me, I do), and yes you can cmd+tab for switching programs, but having a dedicated button when I hold the control key on my keyboard, to have a section on my touch bar for my own programmed, default set of apps (which is one of the cases I use it for) is a plus for me. Of course I sometimes miss the function keys on the mac, but at least I can program the touch bar to show them in some programs where I HAVE to use them (like Teamviewer for giving support to windows users) and Remote desktop (to use a windows machine).

My conclusion is that I love it, and I'm sad to see it go. But I know for sure that when I buy a new Mac, after maybe 4-5 years (I have a MBP 2019 with 4 thunderbolt ports), I will learn to work with a keyboard again without the touch bar. For now, I use it, I love it and maybe Apple will switch to what they had in the past: 2 models. For the persons who like it and want to pay for it and the ones who want a regular keyboard, that would be a perfect world in my eyes.

MicroLED? We all wish, yeah but, you're likely mixing up mini with micro LED.
Surely you meant 'mini LED'... which is an array of white LEDs as a backlight for an LCD panel.
Micro-LED are a true active pixel screen based on little RGB LEDs... on the tens of micrometers scale. Those are still very small volume only and super expensive. But sure... µLED is THE most amazing screen you could theoretically get at this point. The best of both LCD and OLED and even brighter, including super long lifetime.

MagSafe coming back is one of the many things that would make me consider buying Mac again. I lost interest in MacBooks in 2016 because of the changes made to the keyboard, cooling and I/O.
They've walked back on the keyboard and the new silicon largely resolves the cooling issues, so it's only really the IO that is still a big sticking point on these.

The SFF Mac Pro makes a lot of sense considering that unlike with the G4 cube and trashcan, Apple are scaling up their chips to where they need it to be, rather than having to tame down a PPC G4, or a desktop Xeon and a couple of FirePros. Actually it might make more sense for it to be the next top-of-the-line Mac Pro, rather than than migrating the current Xeon-based Mac Pro to Apple Silicon.

For me I'd be interested in an updated 16" MBP, an upgradable headless desktop with serious GPU horsepower that can play AAA games on Ultra detail (I don't think this will ever happen) and an updated iPad Pro.

Some great rumours flying about for sure! I really feel that Apple have finally realised that their innovation matters to content creators.

They need to keep the "influencers" happy as they have access to millions of subscribers, and channels like this explicitly and lucidly talk about the Apple gear they use, and Apple's technical shortcomings to ever increasing audience sizes.

I think this dynamic could bring about a golden age of Mac machine. If the Laptop rumours are true, I would take this as a sign that Apple are listening to us now. Bringing back ports, and omitting tech that didn't take off for most is a good sign. Having said that Apple have been right on many issues, dropping ports early or removing support for coding languages is not always a bad thing in the long run.

Whether it's a Youtube channel depending on a powerhouse video edit sweet or a Music producer like myself. it seems powerful processors that run cool, plenty of I/O, internal hard drive bays, and some upgradability is still a need that isn't going anywhere in the short term.

I feel like the Mac Pro was an expensive response to these ever present needs to the HIGH end of the Pro market, but let's be honest, getting PCI slots and a bigger case is not that much of an innovation, Hackintosh users have been doing this to circumvent Apple's shortcomings for years.

With Apple silicon, we'll likely be saying goodbye to the DIY scene for many years to come, so Apple need to get this right.

So what does an ideal Mac desktop line up look like in 2021?

I've used a 27" iMac to meet my power and budget requirements for a decade, but it's very far from my ideal machine. The highest end Mac mini has always been a compromise in power, The current Mac Pro is too expensive for what it offers most bread and butter professionals. I also think the iMac Pro was/is too much of an investment when the standard 27" iMac 10 core i9 can outperform it in most tasks.

I've always said that I need a high end 27" iMac without the screen. I hate having the fan noise right in front of me when I push my machine, I want my machine under my desk. I also want two 21" displays, but can't because I have to have a 27" to access the high end configurations.

So....I hope that we're not going to see a half sized Mac Pro, but just the re-introduction of a..... "Mac"

No "i" prefix.

No "Pro" or "Mini" Suffix. Just a "Mac".

The equivalent of the inner workings of the highest end iMac with no display, and some space for a couple of hard drives and upgradeable RAM. Upgradeable graphics might be an unrealistic wish, but would please graphics pros no end

That would make my ideal line up of desktops look like this....

Mac Pro
Mac
iMac
Mac Mini

Drop the iMac Pro and make the variable performance parameters of the standard desktop class machines meet the varying needs of the users.

One would hope that Apple has learnt from the mistakes of the past, the G4 cube was terrible as was the trash can. But maybe with Apple silicon... thermal limitations might not be the deal breaking issue that plagued these machines (not including the lack of expansion that led to external drives and a rat's nest of cables coming out of them)

Precisely speaking, microLED and miniLED are different things. MicroLED is  closest to OLED where each pixel can be turned on and off, except that the material is the inorganic semiconductor. MiniLED is the backlight of an LCD display where the LED array is divided into many groups which can be turned on and off separately. What could be anticipated to be on the next iPad or MacBook is, I believe, the miniLED.

I may be in a very specific category as far as the Touch Bar.
• I use my MBP as a closed lid desktop about 95% of the time
• Don’t use the Touch Bar much, but I find value in its UI, and it’s frankly fun
• No physical escape key was absolute sacrilege 🤬 (2018 model)

All in all, I’d prefer if Apple kept it. Yes it’s minimally useful, but I think there’s enough value added that it’s worth keeping (just keep the physical escape key). No matter what, Apple Silicon MBP’s will be a major leap in computing power over Intel. I couldn’t care less about MagSafe (oddly enough, since that’s objectively more useful than Touch Bar). The two must-haves for me are 1) at least 32GB RAM available and 2) multiple monitor support. If so, Apple gets $2500 bones out of my wallet.

Apple always goes back to the old best designs after years of changes that are unpopular.
I will keep upgrading after around 4 years because of these reasons:
Apple puts significantly well-made and robust Chips in the old best designs. Next, it makes design changes by taking away the old best features and It tries to convince buyers that the new ones are better. This is followed by painful 4 years of flaws, errors, fix, then some features become better, the best older ones replace others. Finally, Apple gets the best design with a chip that upgraded a little bit.
Then, Apple brings another even more powerful chip after 4 years and we all give thumbs up to Apple and some people start to complain about old design without realizing that it’s old with the best features. The same happened in 2012, 2016 and 2020.
The next year, Apple takes away other features, brings another design. After a weak, reports of flaws dominate. Then Apple starts another cycle of learning, fixes, etc… for another 4-year period.
In Macs: Apple made the best change with the M1 chip in 2020 and put it in the old design after fixing flaws. 2021 new designs will bring painful flaws that will take 4 years to fix, for all of them. Chips will evolve a little. Not as much as it did in 2020.
So, buy M1 laptop and wait till Apple will learn from new design flaws to buy another mac.

Touch Bar: I must be in that 5% but I have come to quite like and rely on some unique Touch Bar features. For example, when you use the debugger in Xcode to debug an app, you can remotely control the debugger (e.g. enable/disable breakpoints, pause, stepping forward) without switching focus back to Xcode via Cmd-Tab, which is very useful if you need to keep the debugged app in the foreground. The screenshot capturing UI on the Touch Bar is also much more useful and intuitive than having to remember key combos like Cmd-Shift-4 vs Cmd-Shift-Control-3 (without looking it up, I would like to see how many commenters can tell me the difference). I also added a fair amount of support for Touch Bar for my app that I maintain so yes I get that Apple will add and remove features but it does feel sucky that the work is kind of wasted now.

4. Using VIM without a physical escape key messed with muscle memory.
5. I keep hitting siri on accident when hitting backspace. The butterfly keyboard didn't help.

I think the death sentence for the Touch Bar was the fact that Apple never made a desktop option for it. Like, they never sold a standalone touch bar, or a bluetooth keyboard that had one built in. And so nobody with a beefed up iMac or a Mac Pro has access to it. Which means no developers can really take full advantage of it on a productivity level, since it's purely restricted to laptops, which aren't the go-to for big productivity workflows.
If nobody is going all-in on touch bar compatibility, then the hardware just sorta meanders in place until, eventually, Apple trims the fat and removes it completely.

BY FAR the most exciting NEW rumor here, amongst old, been there/done-that rumors, is:

The BLACK MacBook. And NOT because of aesthetics, or cool factor, BUT because they mentioned the light absorption.

Within material sciences, we have Vanta black, Musso black, black 3.0, graphene, and other carbon nanotubes tech.
They all have incredibly exciting applications, but the most exciting and most sensible application for the incorporation of any of these light-absorbing technologies on a laptop, is that the light, AND HEAT, that is absorbed can be CONVERTED INTO ELECTRICITY!

I HIGHLY doubt that Apple is working on this for aesthetic purposes.
Making a matte black laptop just because it’s cool would be super easy, barely an inconvenience. There must be a function/over-design Element behind this rumor.

In addition, you should Google the “1.1° graphene super conductor” 😉

Lastly, When it comes to the available materials Apple could use, that are not currently classified for military usage, could also mean thee lightest and most durable laptop ever made. We’re talking about A laptop shell that can stop a 22 Long rifle, or even a 22 Magnum bullet, with just 2mm to 3mm in thickness!

Since the first announcement, I had the idea that the best approach to the transition was to have a computer come out first that was the 'big bang' and create buzz.... I thought one of those would be the 13" Macbook Pro - but my expectation was it would be the 'Pro' end and not the entry-level end of that line.   The other expectation I had (i.e. what I would do if it were me in charge) -- is to leave the Mac Pro line as is with necessary processor and graphics updates... but come out with a 'consumer' equivalent (I was calling it the 'Mac' <nothing>) of the Mac Pro but still telling professionals that the Mac Pro update was still in development.... Make a version of the consumer 'Mac' that was more powerful for pro tasks, and more powerful graphics than the current model... but aim it more at the developers and power users who don't like all-in-ones.... Let that model entice and make the pro's drool and clammer for their Apple silicon Mac instead of pushing the 'Pro' market to move before they were ready.  It would also give you a good idea of how much more you had to go to fully satisfy the 'Pro's'...

As a man was passing the elephants, he suddenly stopped, confused by the fact that these huge creatures were being held by only a small rope tied to their front leg. No chains, no cages. It was obvious that the elephants could, at anytime, break away from their bonds but for some reason, they did not.
He saw a trainer nearby and asked why these animals just stood there and made no attempt to get away. “Well,” trainer said, “when they are very young and much smaller we use the same size rope to tie them and, at that age, it’s enough to hold them. As they grow up, they are conditioned to believe they cannot break away. They believe the rope can still hold them, so they never try to break free.”
The man was amazed. These animals could at any time break free from their bonds but because they believed they couldn’t, they were stuck right where they were.
Like the elephants, how many of us go through life hanging onto a belief that we cannot do something, simply because we failed at it once before?
Failure is part of learning; we should never give up the struggle in life.

@Cameron Allison In settings you can change what the touch bar shows. You refer to the Air's M1 SoC as a "baseline" level chip that is actually running circles around high-end multicore Intel systems, so why do you believe Apple can't make a Cube-inspired Mac Pro with Apple Silicon that is more powerful than the Intel Mac Pro? Most of that Intel Mac Pro is just cooling fans and a big GPU, right? Apple has proven that they don't need nearly as much cooling for their Silicon as Intel needs for theirs. So I'll predict the exact opposite: The Apple Silicon Cube will be THE Mac Pro, fat GPU included, and the Intel Mac Pro will be a legacy product to continuing supporting x86-native apps like Pro Tools or older Premier workflows (even though, as Apple has also proven with Rosetta 2, that apps compiled for Intel CPUs run faster emulated on the M1 than natively on most Intel systems). I will also say this: You don't need a Touch Bar if you have a touch screen. I think Gurman's rumors are, if nothing else, a little conservative. I think the next MacBook will look as much like today's MacBooks as the iMac G3 looked like the Power Mac 9600.

I’m a mograph artist of 18+ years, a pro user. And the Touch Bar was one reason I stopped using a Mac laptop as a work machine. Functions keys are important. Using them without looking is part of that. I type mostly by feel and I work fast. Touch displays like that bar mean I have to take my eyes off the screen more often. And something about it’s response made it not work correctly with C4D. F8 plays your timeline. For some reason I couldn’t use it to stop playback. There is a delay or command hierarchy that just broke its use on heavier scenes.

Catalina and lack of Nvidia compatibility were bug deciding factors for leaving Mac, but the Touch Bar def made even light use without an external keyboard pretty much impossible.

Good riddance. Bring on the function keys!!!

Please, don't kill the Touch Bar. The Fn keys are not very well utilized within the Mac OS ecosystem anyways and I can find brightness and volume controls almost as fast on a TouchBar as with regular keys. The advantage of the TouchBar is being able to have sliders instead and not having to learn shortcuts for rarely used apps.
A middle ground worth exploring in my opinion would be, to segment the TouchBar into buttons with no space in between. Like the fingerprint sensor but with a display on it.

I'm also not a huge fan of bringing mag safe back. There are numerous magnetic USB-C adapters many of them are not visually intrusive and there even exist models with Thunderbolt support.
The last thing we need is more proprietary charging standards.

A lot of product reviewers are confusing miniLED with microLED.

The miniLED that Marcus and others are talking about is referring to the lcd backlight only. Instead of one source of light behind the lcd (normal displays), miniLED backlit has thousands white LEDs which can independently dim to offer increased contrast.

MicroLED works more like OLED, but better in every way; will eventually replace OLED and high end LCD.

Optimal solution for MagSafe charger on iPhones: Have the magnet only activate when the phone isn't directly aligned on top the charger. When it's aligned, it'll start charging and the magnet inside the charger will stop pulling.

@Henriko Magnifico I know exactly what you said but YOU don't get what I want to say you: Your idea is simply stupid. The MagSafe charging magnet is not THAT strong so that you have problems to pull it off. And just for this tiny bit of force you need, you want to kill most possibilities of MagSafe.

@Tim R. I still don't understand how you don't get what I'm saying. It's simple:

To avoid having the MagSafe charger snap and "get stuck" to the back of the phone, you use an electro magnet instead of a regular magnet inside of the MagSafe charger. Which automatically stops being magnetic the moment the phone gets aligned correctly. So, when you pick up the phone, it's not stuck anymore and you don't need to pry the charger off the phone every single time.

@Henriko Magnifico So you want magnets in both the charger and the phone. What on earth is your point in your "optimal solution" then? Absolutely nothing.
You can buy stands for the Magsafe charger by the way so the phone sits at an angle while charging. This also would be impossible with your "optimal" solution".
Just accept that this idea is nonsense and creates only problems and is a solution for absolutely nothing.
@Tim R. Furthermore, it also would not ”kill” any of the other accessories since only the charger is being altered here.

@Tim R. No, you don’t understand what I’m saying. What I’m proposing is to only have the charger actually utilize electricity to activate it’s own electro magnet inside the charger itself. The phone won’t have to use any power for it’s own magnets since the alignment is only adjusted by the charger and NOT the phone. Hence, iPhone 12 and onward will work great with it because there is no need to redesign the magnets in the backside of the phone for it to work. The charger will know when the phone is charging, and when it is the electro magnet inside the charger gets deactivated. As a result you will be able to easily snap the phone onto the charger and easily lift it off without any pulling.

You're confusing microLED with miniLED. MicroLED is still many years off in small displays, whereas miniLED seems like a likely contender here for next-generation Apple displays.

@MIG? They're entirely different technologies. MiniLED is essentially just a miniaturizing of current FALD LCD panels with many hundred or even thousand backlighting zones, whereas microLED is an inorganic self-emissive technology akin to OLED, but without the risk of burn-in and with potential for far higher peak brightness, and is currently only viable in extremely large 100"+ displays.

what do you think Apple's high-end desktop chips will look like?

A lot of the performance and efficiency of this M1 chip comes from the on-package memory. Having ultra fast, low power memory on-package not only means data can be accessed much faster but it also requires a lot less power to do this compared to normal DIMMs of DDR4, the only issue is it's relatively expensive, especially when you need a lot. I think the entire Apple performance philosophy will rely on this design, so I could see there being a 32GB, 64GB and 128GB version of the CPUs for the high end desktops. Although at $200 per 8GB that would mean a 128GB chip would cost $3200 in RAM alone and that's using the much cheaper DDR4L when I believe they might (should) move to HBM.

There is a chance they will still max out at 16GB or maybe up to 32GB of on-package memory, then rely on having a secondary slower 'normal' RAM option, maybe DDR5 depending when these come out, that can be configured to huge capacities at slightly more palatable prices.

But my money would be on Apple producing a monster chip (similar in design to the Fujitsu A64FX chip) with something like 128GB of ultra fast HBM, 8 layers giving around 4TB/s of bandwidth, to be used as the unified memory for the whole chip which is then directly connected to a PCIE 5 'hyper-drive' SSD over 16 or more lanes. These could actually be very fast, offering up to 128GB/s on PCIE-5 (over 16 lanes). Also PCIE-6 isn't that far off, probably 2023 which doubles this again to 256GB/s. These speeds are actually faster than 8 channels of fast DDR4 and you can make these drives much larger and cheaper! We really could see the death of normal DDR memory on DIMM with a move to ultra fast on-die / on-package system memory plus ultra fast SSDs. Latency might be an issue but a small price to pay for the overall massive performance boost we would see from a shift to system designs like this.

As ever the main enemy on monster chips is heat but ARM architectures have a massive advantage here over x86 plus switching to HBM rather than DDR will help a fair bit too.
I could see the top end Mac Pro Chip in 2021 looking something like this:
32 core CPU (all high performance Firestorm cores)
128 core GPU
128 core Neural Engine
128GB HBM
Built on TSMC's 5nm+ (it's too early for 4nm or 3nm)
Price: ~$15-20k

I think you mean Mini LED. It's not realistic to expect microLED in a mainstream product in 2021. It's still too expensive to be a viable display option. Samsung's microLED 110" TV costs $156K! So, Mini LED first - since it's also rumored to be coming to the 2021 12.9" iPad Pro in a couple of months - then microLED in a few years time. We will likely see microLED on the Apple Watch first, then iPhones, iPads & Macs. Any Apple product that currently has OLED (i.e. Apple Watch & iPhones) will not switch to Mini LED but will likely make to the move to microLED directly.
